This article or section needs for grammar, style, cohesion, tone or spelling. You can assist by editing it now. A how-to is available. (April 2008)''
Banana plants
The Banana industry in the
Caribbean
is widely spread to each island. Bananas are cultivated by both small farmers and large land holders. The plant is perennial and is planted either in pure stands or in mixed cultivation as it is in
Jamaica
. Countries where bananas are a main export crop are
Belize
,
Dominican Republic ,
Honduras ,
Jamaica
, Guadeloupe,
Dominica ,
Martinique , St. Lucia, St. Vincent,
Grenada ,
Nicaragua ,
Panama &
Colombia .
Conditions for Growth
Temperatures = Temperatures should vary from 26C to 31C. The temperature shouldn't fall below 11C.
Rainfall = Rainfall should at least average 1,750 mm per annum and must be well-distributed.
Relief = Heights must not exceed over 300 m for the plant to grow very slowly. Sheltered valleys that are far from strong winds provide good growing conditions since the banana plants have shallow roots and can be easily be uprooted.
Soil = Light, acidic, clay and medium to alluvial soils provide satisfying conditions.
Farming activities
Farming activities include
Land preparation
Cultivation practices
Harvesting & Transportation
Exporting
Land preparation
Mechanical tilling of the land is undertaken on gentle slopes. On flat land, harrowing is carried out to renew the soil fertility.
Cultivation practices
The plant is propagated by roots or from suckers and takes one to reach maturity. Each planting area consists of on bearing plant, one follower and one peeper. When the crop is bearing, bunch sleeving is carried out. Each bunch is covered with a polythene bag and treated with insecticide.
A banana bunch is covered by a polythene bag to prevent diseases
Harvesting & Transportation
When the mature fruit is about 12 months old, it is cut directly from the tree in a green condition. A cutter grooves and cuts the tree near the base while a backer catches the cut bunch. The upper part of the pseudo-stem is not removed as it is suitable for mulching. New plants or suckers are left to grow from the rhizomes. The bananas are carried on the heads of laborers to the nearest road where they are transported by trucks and motor trailers to the packing shed. From the plantations, heavy bunches of bananas are loaded on to cable ways, leading to the packing shed where the choicest fruit is selected for export. As the crop is perishable, timing is of utmost importance. Fruit must be cut within a week's time to meet a shipping load.
Exporting
At the boxing plant, the bananas selected are hung on a convey or and removed hand by hand from the stalk. They are then placed in tanks for at least 4 minutes to wash off the latex and other impurities. Every precautionary method must be taken against skin damage. Wad wrapping and polythene bags are commonly used. The latex flow tends to be absorbed by the wad wrapping.
At the port, the fruit is graded according to quality. It is weighed and placed in refrigerated compartments of the ship at temperatures of 13C. It undergoes regular changes of air to discharge ethylene gases produced by the chemistry of the fruit. In this way, the fruit can withstand long sea journeys and arrive in good condition. Shipping schedules are arranged about 8 weeks in advance.
General Importance of the Banana Industry
Foreign Exchange
The industry provides a very valuable source of foreign exchange. For example, Dominica earned about EC $40 million in 1998 and produced 30,000 tons in 1999.; St.Lucia produced 80,000 tons and earned about EC $87.6 million in 1999; St.Vincent about EC $38.9 million in 1997 and produced 43,000 tons in 1999: Belize earned about BZD $43.16 million in 1998 and produced 78,000 tons in 1999; Jamaica earned about US $29.6 million in 1999 and produced about 130,000 tons & Dominican Republic produced 432,000 tons.
Other Caribbean producing countries are:
Haiti produced 290,000 tons in 1999;
Cuba produced 115,000 tons in 1999;
Colombia produced 1,600,000 tons in 2005;
Costa Rica
produced 2,200,000 tons in 2005;
Mexico
produced 2,000,000 tons in 2005;
Guatemala produced 733,000 tons in 1999;
Honduras produced 861,000 tons in 1999;
Nicaragua produced 69,000 tons in 1999;
Panama produced 650,000 tons &
Venezuela produced 1,000,000 tons.
Creation of Employment
It is a valuable employer of rural labor as it is a labor-intensive industry. In Dominica, it is the second largest employer after government, providing work for 6,000 farmers with another 700 employed at boxing plants. In St.Lucia, it provides employment for about 10,000 workers. In st.Vincent, there are about 5,000 banana growers.
Uses
Bananas are used:
Eaten when ripe;
In making banana flour, baby food, banana chips, banana bread, wine, banana porridge & banana paper.
The juice is used as an ingredient in making dyes.
Banana stem for cloth.
Produce rope from the dried stock
Used bananas as animal feed and so reduce the current imports.
Problems facing the Banana Industry
1. Small Size of Farms
The small size of farms makes for inefficient production and contributes to a low standard of living. In Dominica, 8% of the fruit is supplied by 51% of the banana farming population, medium growers supply 41% and over 51% is supplied by large land holders. In the Windward group generally, the majority of the farming population owns less than a third of the banana acreage. In Grenada, there are a large number of peasant plots given to intercrop cultivation with bananas. In St.Vincent, the pattern is the same, although output is greater from the estates. The small size of farms provides a low income to farmers as they are unable to apply fertilizers or minimize the risk of insect pests and diseases.
2. High Costs & Competition from other producing countries
Low income returns to farmers are experienced when low prices are offered though shipping and marketing agents. As a result, farmers are unable to effectively increase their production. They are unable to apply fertilizers or to minimize risks caused by diseases. The industry is plagued with high costs and low prices. Bananas are also plentiful in
Latin America
&
Africa
, thus imposing a threat to the Caribbean's position on the British market.The
United Kingdom
imports a high percentage of their fruit from the
Caribbean
. Too great a supply reduces the price of the fruit. This is an economic disadvantage since the fruit is perishable within short period.
3. Diseases
In Grenada, the Moko disease (
Ralstonia solanacearum
) has caused much destruction in the northern part of the island while it has eradicated the industry in Trinidad and Tobago out of commercial production during the 1960s.
Black sigatoka
(Mycosphaerella fijiensis) causes premature ripening of the fruit. It has wiped out 40% of Dominica's 4,000 ha of banana cultivation. Even when the fruit is exported there is a high incidence of ship-ripe fruit which arrive at their destination in poor condition.
Panama disease( Fusarium oxysporum)is caused by tiny worms which feed on the roots of the plants, block the water vessels and reduce production. Production is also affected by pests which scar the banana peel. The placing of sleeves over the bunches and the removal of the buds are 2 controlling measures.
World banana production
· Belize · Caribbean · Côte d'Ivoire · Honduras · Iceland · Panama
